title: Adding ordered path to your ternary plot
text: Take example 2022 Australian Federal Election, like take look changes preference distribution across rounds three electorates: Higgins, Monash, Melbourne. Input data already ternable-friendly format, row representing preference distribution one round voting one electorate. 2D ternary plots, adding ordered paths straightforward using stat_ordered_path() function, providing order_by aesthetic. equivalent geom_path() pre-order data points order want connected. case, want connect points order round (order_by = CountNumber) electorate (group = DivisionNm).  ’s interesting see close win ALP Higgins (red line) since result flipped last round. Meanwhile, wins Monash Melbourne consistent first preference.
code: aecdop22_widen <- prefviz:::aecdop22_widen input_df <- aecdop22_widen |>     filter(DivisionNm %in% c("Higgins", "Monash", "Melbourne")) head(input_df) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty   ALP   LNP Other #>   <chr>            <dbl> <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Higgins              0 ALP          0.285 0.407 0.309 #> 2 Higgins              1 ALP          0.285 0.407 0.307 #> 3 Higgins              2 ALP          0.288 0.409 0.303 #> 4 Higgins              3 ALP          0.292 0.411 0.297 #> 5 Higgins              4 ALP          0.294 0.416 0.290 #> 6 Higgins              5 ALP          0.300 0.448 0.252  # Create ternable object tern22 <- ternable(input_df, ALP:Other) # The base plot p <- get_tern_data(tern22, plot_type = "2D") |>    ggplot(aes(x = x1, y = x2)) +   geom_ternary_cart() +   geom_ternary_region(     aes(fill = after_stat(vertex_labels)),     vertex_labels = tern22$vertex_labels,     alpha = 0.3, color = "grey50",     show.legend = FALSE   ) +   geom_point(aes(color = ElectedParty)) +   add_vertex_labels(tern22$simplex_vertices) +   scale_color_manual(     values = c("ALP" = "red", "LNP" = "blue", "Other" = "grey70"),     aesthetics = c("fill", "colour")   )  # Add ordered paths p + stat_ordered_path(   aes(group = DivisionNm, order_by = CountNumber, color = ElectedParty),    size = 0.5 )

title: Adding ordered path to your ternary plot
text: Let’s take look Monash Melbourne 2025 election, time use high-dimensional ternary plot 5 parties: ALP, LNP, GRN, IND, . Unlike 2D ternary plots, need group order data plotting providing group order_by arguments creating ternable object. Since data already ordered round input data frame, just need provide grouping variable (DivisionNm). Adding paths high-dimensional ternary plot made possible edges arguments display_xy(). Therefore, besides simplex edges, need provide data edges edges argument. can done setting include_data = TRUE get_tern_edges().
code: aecdop25_widen <- prefviz:::aecdop25_widen input_df2 <- aecdop25_widen |>   filter(DivisionNm %in% c("Monash", "Melbourne")) head(input_df2) #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty   ALP   GRN   LNP Other    IND #>   <chr>            <dbl> <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 Melbourne            0 ALP          0.313     0 0.198 0.439 0.0495 #> 2 Melbourne            1 ALP          0.316     0 0.199 0.444 0.0408 #> 3 Melbourne            2 ALP          0.321     0 0.201 0.434 0.0444 #> 4 Melbourne            3 ALP          0.326     0 0.212 0.408 0.0538 #> 5 Melbourne            4 ALP          0.343     0 0.236 0.421 0      #> 6 Melbourne            5 ALP          0.530     0 0     0.470 0  # Create ternable object tern25 <- ternable(input_df2, ALP:IND, group = DivisionNm) # Add colors party_colors <- c(   "ALP" = "#E13940",    # Red   "LNP" = "#1C4F9C",    # Blue   "GRN" = "#10C25B",    # Green   "IND" = "#F39C12",    # Orange   "Other" = "#95A5A6"   # Gray )  color_vector <- c(rep("black", 5),   party_colors[input_df2$ElectedParty])  edges_color <- c(rep("black", nrow(tern25$simplex_edges)),   party_colors[input_df2$ElectedParty])  # Animate the tour animate_xy(   get_tern_data(tern25, plot_type = "HD"),    col = color_vector,   edges = get_tern_edges(tern25, include_data = TRUE),   edges.col = edges_color,   obs_labels  = get_tern_labels(tern25),   axes = "bottomleft" )

title: Using `ternable` object to draw ternary plots
text: ternable simple S3 object contains data metadata useful ternary plots, including following components: data: Stores input data validated normalized data_coord: Stores coordinates observations. data_edges: Stores connections observations. Useful want create paths observations. simplex_vertices: Stores simplex vertices’ coordinates. simplex_edges: Stores connections simplex vertices. vertex_labels: Stores vertex labels/item names order provided argument items. create ternable object, simply call function ternable(). ternable() takes 2 arguments: data: input data, must ternable-friendly format. details transform raw data ternable-friendly format, please refer vignette("transform_raw_data") items: item names order want appear ternary plot. default takes columns data.
code: aecdop22_transformed <- prefviz:::aecdop22_transformed head(aecdop22_transformed) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty   ALP   LNP Other #>   <chr>            <dbl> <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Adelaide             0 ALP          0.400 0.32  0.280 #> 2 Aston                0 LNP          0.325 0.430 0.244 #> 3 Ballarat             0 ALP          0.447 0.271 0.282 #> 4 Banks                0 LNP          0.353 0.452 0.195 #> 5 Barker               0 LNP          0.209 0.556 0.235 #> 6 Barton               0 ALP          0.504 0.262 0.234  tern22 <- ternable(data = aecdop22_transformed, items = ALP:Other) tern22 #> Ternable object #> ---------------- #> Items: ALP, LNP, Other  #> Vertices: 3  #> Edges: 6

title: Using `ternable` object to draw ternary plots
text: ternable provides essenstial components building ternary plot, different plot types (2D HD) might require slightly different way representing commponents. get_tern_*() functions help just . hood, get_tern_*() perform simple data transformations, .e., rbind() cbind(), help create input compatible popular plotting packages, .e., ggplot2 2D ternary plot tourr HD ternary plots. 3 get_tern_*() functions: get_tern_data(): Provides input data ggplot2 tourr. get_tern_edges(): Provides edges simplex, required tourr. get_tern_labels(): Provides labels vertices, helpful distinguishing vertices tourr.

title: Using `ternable` object to draw ternary plots
text: Take example 2022 Australian Federal Election, like take look first preference distribution 2 major parties: Labor Coalition, parties. dataset aecdop22_transformed already ternable-friendly format, can directly pass ternable() create ternable object. Now can use get_tern_data() function get input data ggplot2. output data frame original columns combined coordinates (x1, x2). coordinate columns observation locations plot. can now use ggplot2 draw ternary plot.  election, interested defining regions one party takes majority others. can using geom_ternary_region(). geom takes barycentric coordinates reference point input, divides ternary triangle 3 regions based reference points. regions defined perpendicular projections reference point three edges triangle. default reference point centroid, divides triangle 3 equal regions.  vertex_labels argument used specify vertex region belongs . helpful want “sync” aesthetic mapping geom_ternary_region() base layer need specify customization . Please note order labels provided must match order vertices ternary plot. vertices listed clockwise, right (ALP) left (LNP), ending top triangle (). best way get labels ternable$vertex_labels ternable preserves vertex orders.
code: tern22 <- ternable(aecdop22_transformed, ALP:Other) input_df <- get_tern_data(tern22, plot_type = "2D") head(input_df) #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty    ALP    LNP  Other          x1 #> 1   Adelaide           0          ALP 0.3998 0.3200 0.2802  0.05642712 #> 2      Aston           0          LNP 0.3255 0.4305 0.2440 -0.07424621 #> 3   Ballarat           0          ALP 0.4474 0.2709 0.2817  0.12480435 #> 4      Banks           0          LNP 0.3526 0.4522 0.1952 -0.07042784 #> 5     Barker           0          LNP 0.2085 0.5563 0.2352 -0.24593174 #> 6     Barton           0          ALP 0.5043 0.2619 0.2338  0.17140268 #>            x2 #> 1 -0.06507478 #> 2 -0.10941054 #> 3 -0.06323766 #> 4 -0.16917809 #> 5 -0.12018830 #> 6 -0.12190294 p <- ggplot(input_df, aes(x = x1, y = x2)) +   # Draw the ternary space as an equilateral triangle   geom_ternary_cart() +    # Plot the observations as points   geom_point(aes(color = ElectedParty)) +    # Add vertex labels, taken from the ternable object   add_vertex_labels(tern22$simplex_vertices) +    labs(title = "First preference in 2022 Australian Federal election")  p p +    geom_ternary_region(     x1 = 1/3, x2 = 1/3, x3 = 1/3, # Default reference points. Must sum to 1     vertex_labels = tern22$vertex_labels, # Labels for the regions     aes(fill = after_stat(vertex_labels)),      alpha = 0.3, color = NA, show.legend = FALSE   ) +   scale_fill_manual(     values = c("ALP" = "red", "LNP" = "blue", "Other" = "grey70"),     aesthetics = c("fill", "colour")   )

title: Using `ternable` object to draw ternary plots
text: Take example 2025 Australian Federal Election, like take look first preference distribution 4 major groups: Labor, Coalition, Greens, Independents party. can conveniently done using tourr package, ternable object get_tern_*() functions. ternary tour requires following components: Coordinates observations vertices Edges simplex Vertex labels (good identify vertices tour)  can add colors points.
code: # Load the data aecdop25_transformed <- prefviz:::aecdop25_transformed head(aecdop25_transformed) #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty   ALP    GRN   LNP Other    IND #>   <chr>            <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 Adelaide             0 ALP          0.465 0.190  0.242 0.104 0      #> 2 Aston                0 ALP          0.373 0      0.377 0.209 0.0414 #> 3 Ballarat             0 ALP          0.424 0      0.286 0.262 0.0281 #> 4 Banks                0 ALP          0.364 0.119  0.391 0.106 0.0202 #> 5 Barker               0 LNP          0.225 0.0816 0.5   0.135 0.0586 #> 6 Barton               0 ALP          0.471 0.159  0.242 0.128 0  tern25 <- ternable(aecdop25_transformed, ALP:IND)  # Animate the tour animate_xy(   get_tern_data(tern25, plot_type = "HD"), # Dataframe with coordinates of the observations and vertices   edges = get_tern_edges(tern25), # Edges of the simplex   obs_labels  = get_tern_labels(tern25), # Labels for the vertices   axes = "bottomleft" ) # Define color mapping party_colors <- c(   "ALP" = "#E13940",    # Red   "LNP" = "#1C4F9C",    # Blue   "GRN" = "#10C25B",    # Green   "IND" = "#F39C12",    # Orange   "Other" = "#95A5A6"   # Gray )  # Map to your data (assuming your column is called elected_party) color_vector <- c(rep("black", 5),   party_colors[aecdop25_transformed$ElectedParty])  # Animate the tour animate_xy(   get_tern_data(tern25, plot_type = "HD"),    edges = get_tern_edges(tern25),   obs_labels  = get_tern_labels(tern25),   col = color_vector,   axes = "bottomleft" )

title: Transforming voting data to ternable-friendly format
text: Raw voting data comes shapes forms, voting data can easily transformed format ready ternary plots. vignette shows transform common voting data formats ternable-friendly format can used ternary plots. include PrefLib-formatted data, raw ballot data long wide forms, AEC distribution preference data.

title: Transforming voting data to ternable-friendly format
text: ternable() creates ternable object, S3 object contains data metadata necessary ternary plots. ternable-friendly data frame must following characteristics: least 3 numeric columns representing preferences 3 items/candidates election. columns act vertices ternary plot. Values item/candidate columns must non-negative, sum 1. data frame minimal example ternable-friendly data frame. contains 3 columns, representing preferences party specific electorate. values columns non-negative sum 1.
code: df <- tibble(   electorate = c("A", "B", "C"),   PartyA = c(0.5, 0.4, 0.6),   PartyB = c(0.3, 0.4, 0.2),   PartyC = c(0.2, 0.2, 0.2) )  df #> # A tibble: 3 × 4 #>   electorate PartyA PartyB PartyC #>   <chr>       <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 A             0.5    0.3    0.2 #> 2 B             0.4    0.4    0.2 #> 3 C             0.6    0.2    0.2

title: Transforming voting data to ternable-friendly format
text: PrefLib format common format storing preferential data, can easily downloaded using prefio::read_preflib() function. example, use NSW Legislative Assembly Election dataset. dataset contains preferential data, row representing unique set preferences respective frequencies. missing transform data ternable-friendly format breakdown preferences candidate round voting. function dop_irv() package helps us simulate Instant Runoff Voting (IRV) process get round--round preferences candidate, transform data ternable-friendly format. caveat function handle ties preferences given ballot, works fine Australian IRV rules, may appropriate electoral systems.
code: nswla <- read_preflib("00058 - nswla/00058-00000171.soi", from_preflib = TRUE) nswla #> # A tibble: 1,104 × 2 #> # ℹ 1,094 more rows #> # ℹ 2 more variables: preferences <prefrncs>, frequency <int> dop_irv(   nswla, value_type = "percentage",   preferences_col = preferences,   frequency_col = frequency) #> # A tibble: 4 × 8 #>   round `HAYLEN Jo` `WEI Leo` `RAUE Tom` `MAKRIS Andrea` `ROMANOVSKY Teresa` #>   <int>       <dbl>     <dbl>      <dbl>           <dbl>               <dbl> #> 1     1       0.464     0.233      0.206          0.0572              0.0252 #> 2     2       0.469     0.236      0.209          0.0595              0.0270 #> 3     3       0.478     0.240      0.218          0.0646              0      #> 4     4       0.504     0.253      0.244          0                   0      #> # ℹ 2 more variables: `SINDEN Dale` <dbl>, winner <chr>

what: Raw ballot data in long and wide formats
title: Transforming voting data to ternable-friendly format
text: Raw ballot data mostly comes long wide format. formats can transformed Preflib format, can converted ternable-friendly format using dop_irv(). Processing long format Consider following example simulated ballot data long format Melbourne electorate, 3 parties: ALP, LNP, , typical column preference rank. Processing wide format Consider example, wide format, column representing item/candidate value representing preference rank.
code: # Convert to PrefLib format preflib_long <- prefio::long_preferences(   ballot_long,   vote,   id_cols = c(ballot_id, elect_division),   item_col = party,   rank_col = preference_rank )  # Convert to ternable-friendly format dop_irv(preflib_long$vote, value_type = "percentage") #> # A tibble: 2 × 5 #>   round   ALP   LNP Other winner #>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  #> 1     1   0.4   0.2   0.4 ALP    #> 2     2   0.6   0     0.4 ALP # Convert to PrefLib format preflib_wide <- prefio::wide_preferences(ballot_wide, vote, ALP:Other)  # Convert to ternable-friendly format dop_irv(preflib_wide$vote, value_type = "percentage") #> # A tibble: 2 × 5 #>   round   ALP   LNP Other winner #>   <int> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  #> 1     1   0.4   0.2   0.4 ALP    #> 2     2   0.6   0     0.4 ALP

title: Transforming voting data to ternable-friendly format
text: section applies specifically AEC distribution preferences data. However, can also adapted datasets similar format, row represents aggregated preference count /percentage specific candidate specific group/electorate. must least primary key column uniquely identifies row, value column representing preference count/percentage, item column representing items/parties. may also column representing electoral status item/party (elected elected). optional. example, work 2025 Distribution Preference data, included package aecdop_2025. interested preference percentages 4 main parties: Labor, Coalition, Greens, Independents. rest grouped . transforming data, let’s data wrangling filter relevant information. data now ready transformation, following characteristics: DivisionNm CountNumber columns together form primary key uniquely identifies row. CalculationValue column contains preference percentage. Party column contains item/party. Elected column contains elected/electoral status party. use dop_transform() function transform data ternable-friendly format.
code: # only include preference percentage and parties of interest  aecdop_2025 <- aecdop_2025 |>    filter(CalculationType == "Preference Percent") |>   mutate(Party = case_when(     # all parties not in the main parties are grouped into "Other"     !(PartyAb %in% c("LP", "ALP", "NP", "LNP", "LNQ", "GRN", "IND")) ~ "Other",      # group all parties in the Coalition into "LNP"     PartyAb %in% c("LP", "NP", "LNP", "LNQ") ~ "LNP",     TRUE ~ PartyAb   )) dop_transform(   data = aecdop_2025,   key_cols = c(DivisionNm, CountNumber),   value_col = CalculationValue,   item_col = Party,   winner_col = Elected,   winner_identifier = "Y" ) #> # A tibble: 976 × 8 #>    DivisionNm CountNumber   ALP   GRN   LNP  Other    IND Winner #>    <chr>            <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl>  <dbl> <chr>  #>  1 Adelaide             0 0.465 0.190 0.242 0.104  0      ALP    #>  2 Adelaide             1 0.467 0.194 0.242 0.0967 0      ALP    #>  3 Adelaide             2 0.476 0.205 0.244 0.0745 0      ALP    #>  4 Adelaide             3 0.483 0.210 0.249 0.0578 0      ALP    #>  5 Adelaide             4 0.493 0.222 0.285 0      0      ALP    #>  6 Adelaide             5 0.691 0     0.309 0      0      ALP    #>  7 Aston                0 0.373 0     0.377 0.209  0.0414 ALP    #>  8 Aston                1 0.373 0     0.378 0.206  0.0434 ALP    #>  9 Aston                2 0.376 0     0.380 0.210  0.0338 ALP    #> 10 Aston                3 0.378 0     0.384 0.202  0.0358 ALP    #> # ℹ 966 more rows

what: Visualizes preference data via ternary plots in two and higher dimensions
title: Visualizes preference data via ternary plots in two and higher dimensions
text: Ternary plot one popular ways visualize preference data, preferential elections voters rank candidates ordinally. Traditionally, ternary plot works 3-part compositional variables, representing 3 vertices 2D equilateral triangle. However, many cases, preference data consists 3 alternatives, making 2D ternary plot inadequate visualize data. prefviz provides solution creating ternary plots two higher dimensions. plots made compatible interactivity R packages, allowing users explore ternary plot interactively.

title: Visualizes preference data via ternary plots in two and higher dimensions
text: can install development version prefviz via:
code: # install.packages("devtools") remotes::install_github("numbats/prefviz")

title: Visualizes preference data via ternary plots in two and higher dimensions
text: optimal compatibility, suggest data alternatives/composition columns columns sum 1. can explore wrapper functions dop_irv() dop_transform() assist transformation.
code: aecdop22_transformed <- prefviz:::aecdop22_transformed head(aecdop22_transformed) |> select(-CountNumber, -ElectedParty) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   DivisionNm   ALP   LNP Other #>   <chr>      <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Adelaide   0.400 0.32  0.280 #> 2 Aston      0.325 0.430 0.244 #> 3 Ballarat   0.447 0.271 0.282 #> 4 Banks      0.353 0.452 0.195 #> 5 Barker     0.209 0.556 0.235 #> 6 Barton     0.504 0.262 0.234

title: Visualizes preference data via ternary plots in two and higher dimensions
text: Every ternary plot made 3 components: Coordinates observations: n-part compositional data must transformed (n-1)-dimensional space via Helmert matrix. Vertices: point coordinates define vertices simplex Edges: vertices connected create simplex components provided ternable object, can accessed directly object via getter functions get_tern_*(). get_tern_*() functions transform components ternable object suitable input data ggplot2 tourr. Consider distribution first-round preferences 2022 Australian Federal Election: can create ternable object using ternable() function:
code: aecdop22_transformed <- prefviz:::aecdop22_transformed head(aecdop22_transformed) #> # A tibble: 6 × 6 #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty   ALP   LNP Other #>   <chr>            <dbl> <chr>        <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Adelaide             0 ALP          0.400 0.32  0.280 #> 2 Aston                0 LNP          0.325 0.430 0.244 #> 3 Ballarat             0 ALP          0.447 0.271 0.282 #> 4 Banks                0 LNP          0.353 0.452 0.195 #> 5 Barker               0 LNP          0.209 0.556 0.235 #> 6 Barton               0 ALP          0.504 0.262 0.234 tern22 <- ternable(aecdop22_transformed, ALP:Other) tern22 #> Ternable object #> ---------------- #> Items: ALP, LNP, Other  #> Vertices: 3  #> Edges: 6

title: Visualizes preference data via ternary plots in two and higher dimensions
code: # Get the input data input_df <- get_tern_data(tern22, plot_type = "2D") head(input_df) #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty    ALP    LNP  Other          x1 #> 1   Adelaide           0          ALP 0.3998 0.3200 0.2802  0.05642712 #> 2      Aston           0          LNP 0.3255 0.4305 0.2440 -0.07424621 #> 3   Ballarat           0          ALP 0.4474 0.2709 0.2817  0.12480435 #> 4      Banks           0          LNP 0.3526 0.4522 0.1952 -0.07042784 #> 5     Barker           0          LNP 0.2085 0.5563 0.2352 -0.24593174 #> 6     Barton           0          ALP 0.5043 0.2619 0.2338  0.17140268 #>            x2 #> 1 -0.06507478 #> 2 -0.10941054 #> 3 -0.06323766 #> 4 -0.16917809 #> 5 -0.12018830 #> 6 -0.12190294  # Visualize ggplot(input_df, aes(x = x1, y = x2)) +   geom_ternary_cart() +   geom_ternary_region(     vertex_labels = tern22$vertex_labels,     aes(fill = after_stat(vertex_labels)),      alpha = 0.3, color = "grey50",     show.legend = FALSE   ) +   geom_point(aes(color = ElectedParty)) +   add_vertex_labels(tern22$simplex_vertices) +   scale_fill_manual(     values = c("ALP" = "red", "LNP" = "blue", "Other" = "grey70"),     aesthetics = c("fill", "colour")   ) +   labs(title = "First preference in 2022 Australian Federal election")

title: Visualizes preference data via ternary plots in two and higher dimensions
code: # Load the data aecdop25_transformed <- prefviz:::aecdop25_transformed head(aecdop25_transformed) #> # A tibble: 6 × 8 #>   DivisionNm CountNumber ElectedParty   ALP    GRN   LNP Other    IND #>   <chr>            <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> #> 1 Adelaide             0 ALP          0.465 0.190  0.242 0.104 0      #> 2 Aston                0 ALP          0.373 0      0.377 0.209 0.0414 #> 3 Ballarat             0 ALP          0.424 0      0.286 0.262 0.0281 #> 4 Banks                0 ALP          0.364 0.119  0.391 0.106 0.0202 #> 5 Barker               0 LNP          0.225 0.0816 0.5   0.135 0.0586 #> 6 Barton               0 ALP          0.471 0.159  0.242 0.128 0  # Create ternable object tern25 <- ternable(aecdop25_transformed, ALP:IND)  # Add colors to the points party_colors <- c(   "ALP" = "#E13940",    # Red   "LNP" = "#1C4F9C",    # Blue   "GRN" = "#10C25B",    # Green   "IND" = "#F39C12",    # Orange   "Other" = "#95A5A6"   # Gray )  # Map to your data color_vector <- c(rep("black", 5),   party_colors[aecdop25_transformed$ElectedParty])  # Animate the tour animate_xy(   get_tern_data(tern25, plot_type = "HD"),    edges = get_tern_edges(tern25),   obs_labels  = get_tern_labels(tern25),   col = color_vector,   axes = "bottomleft" )

what: Get full distribution of preferences in each instant runoff voting round as percentage — dop_irv
title: Get full distribution of preferences in each instant runoff voting round as percentage — dop_irv
text: Compute preference round instant runoff voting input data, transforming results tidy format visualization. row represents one round, columns candidate's preference percentage election winner.

title: Get full distribution of preferences in each instant runoff voting round as percentage — dop_irv
code: dop_irv(x, value_type = c("percentage", "count"), ...)

title: Get full distribution of preferences in each instant runoff voting round as percentage — dop_irv
text: x Input data. Accepts formats prefio::pref_irv(): preference vector element represents one ballot data frame column preference value_type Character string specifying output format. Either: "percentage" (default): Returns vote shares proportions (0-1) "count": Returns raw vote counts ... Additional arguments passed prefio::pref_irv(), including: preferences_col: Column name containing preference orderings frequency_col: Column name containing vote frequencies

title: Get full distribution of preferences in each instant runoff voting round as percentage — dop_irv
text: tibble following structure: round: Integer, round number (1 n) One column per candidate: Numeric, percentage votes (0-1) candidate received round. NA values replaced 0 eliminated candidates. winner: Character, name eventual IRV winner (rows)

title: Get full distribution of preferences in each instant runoff voting round as percentage — dop_irv
code: # Example 1: From preference vector votes <- c("A > B > C", "B > A > C", "C > B > A", "A > B > C") dop_irv(votes, value_type = "count") #> # A tibble: 0 × 0  # Example 2: From data frame with custom column names vote_data <- tibble::tibble(   prefs = c("A > B > C", "B > C > A", "C > A > B"),   counts = c(100, 75, 25) ) dop_irv(vote_data, value_type = "percentage",         preferences_col = prefs,         frequency_col = counts) #> # A tibble: 0 × 0

title: Transform AEC distribution of preferences from long to wide format — dop_transform
code: dop_transform(   data,   key_cols,   value_col,   item_col,   normalize = TRUE,   scale = 1,   fill_value = 0,   winner_col = NULL,   winner_identifier = "Y" )

title: Transform AEC distribution of preferences from long to wide format — dop_transform
text: data data frame containing preference vote distribution data, format similar https://results.aec.gov.au/31496/Website/Downloads/HouseDopByDivisionDownload-31496.csv key_cols Columns identify unique observations, e.g., DivisionNm, CountNumber value_col Numeric non-negative. Column containing numeric values aggregate, e.g., CalculationValue, Votes. item_col Column name containing items (candidates/parties) election, e.g., Party, Candidate. column become column names output wide format. normalize Logical. TRUE (default), normalizes values within group sum 1. FALSE, returns raw aggregated values. scale Numeric. normalize = FALSE, divides values scale factor. Default 1 (scaling). fill_value Numeric. Value use missing combinations pivoting. Default 0. winner_col Optional character string specifying column indicates winner/elected party. provided, column joined back output based key columns. Useful preserving election outcome information. Default NULL. winner_identifier Optional character string specifying value winner_col identifies winning candidates (e.g., "Y", "Elected"). used winner_col specified. Default "Y".

title: Transform AEC distribution of preferences from long to wide format — dop_transform
text: data frame wide format : Key columns identifying observation Columns item (candidate/party) containing aggregated/normalized values Winner column (winner_col specified)

title: Transform AEC distribution of preferences from long to wide format — dop_transform
code: # Convert AEC 2025 Distribution of Preference data to wide format data(aecdop_2025)  # We are interested in the preferences of Labor, Coalition, Greens and Independent.  # The rest of the parties are aggregated as Other. aecdop_2025 <- aecdop_2025 |>  filter(CalculationType == "Preference Percent") |>    mutate(PartyAb = case_when(     !(PartyAb %in% c("LP", "ALP", "NP", "LNP", "LNQ")) ~ "Other",     PartyAb %in% c("LP", "NP", "LNP", "LNQ") ~ "LNP",    TRUE ~ PartyAb)) #> Error in mutate(filter(aecdop_2025, CalculationType == "Preference Percent"),     PartyAb = case_when(!(PartyAb %in% c("LP", "ALP", "NP", "LNP",         "LNQ")) ~ "Other", PartyAb %in% c("LP", "NP", "LNP",         "LNQ") ~ "LNP", TRUE ~ PartyAb)): could not find function "mutate"  dop_transform(   data = aecdop_2025,   key_cols = c(DivisionNm, CountNumber),   value_col = CalculationValue,   item_col = Party,   winner_col = Elected ) #> Error in dop_transform(data = aecdop_2025, key_cols = c(DivisionNm, CountNumber),     value_col = CalculationValue, item_col = Party, winner_col = Elected): Columns not found in data: Party

text: geom_ternary_region() stat_ternary_region() divide ternary triangle three polygonal regions centered around specific reference point. title: Create polygonal regions in a ternary plot based on a reference point — geom_ternary_region
text: stat_ternary_region() calculates following variables can accessed after_stat(): x, y Cartesian coordinates defining polygon shapes. id Numeric identifier specific geometric points used build polygons: 1-3: main vertices ternary triangle. 4: reference point (center). 5-7: projection points edges. group Integer (1, 2, 3) identifying region polygon belongs . vertex_labels label assigned region (derived vertex_labels parameter).

code: aecdop22_transformed <- prefviz:::aecdop22_transformed  # Get ternable tern22 <- ternable(aecdop22_transformed, ALP:Other)  # Draw the ternary plot ggplot(get_tern_data(tern22, plot_type = "2D"), aes(x = x1, y = x2)) +   geom_ternary_cart() +   geom_ternary_region(     vertex_labels = tern22$vertex_labels,     aes(fill = after_stat(vertex_labels)),      alpha = 0.3, color = "grey50",     show.legend = FALSE   )

title: Transform compositional data using Helmert matrix — helmert_transform
text: data data frame matrix containing compositional data. items <tidy-select> Columns representing components composition. Default tidyselect::everything(), selects columns. Must select least 3 columns. append (Optional) logical value indicating whether transformed data appended original data frame. Default FALSE.

title: Transform compositional data using Helmert matrix — helmert_transform
text: data frame containing Helmert-transformed coordinates, named x1, x2, ..., x(n-1), n number items. append = TRUE, columns added input data.

title: Transform compositional data using Helmert matrix — helmert_transform
code: # Example 1: Transform a matrix (all columns) comp_mat <- matrix(c(0.5, 0.3, 0.2,                      0.4, 0.4, 0.2,                      0.6, 0.2, 0.2),                    ncol = 3, byrow = TRUE) helmert_transform(comp_mat) #>             x1        x2 #> 1 1.414214e-01 0.1632993 #> 2 2.671291e-18 0.1632993 #> 3 2.828427e-01 0.1632993  # Example 2: Transform specific columns in a data frame df <- data.frame(   electorate = c("A", "B", "C"),   ALP = c(0.5, 0.4, 0.6),   LNP = c(0.3, 0.4, 0.2),   Other = c(0.2, 0.2, 0.2) ) helmert_transform(df, items = c(ALP, LNP, Other)) #>             x1        x2 #> 1 1.414214e-01 0.1632993 #> 2 2.671291e-18 0.1632993 #> 3 2.828427e-01 0.1632993

title: Reorder observations for a path geom — stat_ordered_path
text: ggplot2 layer can added plot object.

title: Reorder observations for a path geom — stat_ordered_path
text: statistic expects order_by aesthetic supplies variable used order observations within group. Missing values order_by handled according na_method. na_method "drop_na", missing values dropped data, path still drawn, might skipping steps due missing values. na_method "drop_group", entire group whose missing values belong dropped data, path drawn. Ties order_by allowed trigger warning preserve original row order tied values. Duplicates order_by dropped warning issued. Grouping controlled via usual group aesthetic. group column present data, reordering performed independently within group; otherwise, entire data treated single path.

code: # Data prep input_df <- prefviz:::aecdop22_widen |>     filter(DivisionNm %in% c("Higgins", "Monash")) #> Error: object 'DivisionNm' not found tern22 <- ternable(input_df, ALP:Other) #> Error: object 'input_df' not found  # Base plot p <- get_tern_data(tern22, plot_type = "2D") |>    ggplot(aes(x = x1, y = x2)) +   geom_ternary_cart() +   geom_ternary_region(     aes(fill = after_stat(vertex_labels)),     vertex_labels = tern22$vertex_labels,     alpha = 0.3, color = "grey50",     show.legend = FALSE   ) +   geom_point(aes(color = ElectedParty)) +   add_vertex_labels(tern22$simplex_vertices) +   scale_color_manual(     values = c("ALP" = "red", "LNP" = "blue", "Other" = "grey70"),     aesthetics = c("fill", "colour")   ) #> Error: object 'tern22' not found  # Add ordered paths p +    stat_ordered_path(     aes(group = DivisionNm, order_by = CountNumber, color = ElectedParty),      size = 0.5) #> Error: object 'p' not found
